title: Sacred Places & Mythical Realms
shortDescription: Divine realms, sacred mountains, underworlds, and legendary locations
description: Journey to the places where heaven touches earth and the underworld opens its gates. Explore Mount Olympus, Valhalla, the Garden of Eden, Shangri-La, and the countless sacred sites that anchor mythology in cosmic geography.

sections.title: The Geography of the Sacred
sections.body:
Every mythology maps the cosmos, creating a sacred geography where divine and mortal realms intersect. These are the axis mundi‚Äîworld centers like Yggdrasil, Mount Meru, and the Temple Mount‚Äîwhere heaven, earth, and underworld connect. They are the destinations of heroes' journeys, the homes of gods, and the gateways between worlds.

Some places exist purely in myth: Mount Olympus as the gleaming home of Greek gods, Valhalla where slain warriors feast, the Pure Land of Buddhist paradise. Others are real locations invested with mythic significance: Jerusalem as the center of the world, the Ganges as the river of heaven, Mount Fuji as the bridge to the divine. Each tradition creates its own sacred map, teaching fundamental truths about cosmology, morality, and humanity's place in the universe.

sections.title: Mapping the Cosmos
sections.body:
Mythological geography reveals how cultures structured the universe. Many traditions employ a three-tier cosmos: heaven above (realm of gods), earth in the middle (realm of mortals), and underworld below (realm of the dead). Norse mythology complexifies this with Nine Realms arranged on Yggdrasil. Buddhist and Hindu cosmologies feature multiple heavens and hells arranged in vertical layers.

At the center stands the axis mundi‚Äîa cosmic pole, mountain, tree, or temple that connects all levels. This sacred center is where shamans journey between worlds, where prayers ascend to heaven, where divine power flows to earth. It represents the possibility of transcendence, the connection between human and divine, the navigation point in an otherwise chaotic cosmos.

sections.title: Places of Pilgrimage and Quest
sections.body:
Sacred places are destinations. Heroes journey to the underworld to rescue the dead or gain forbidden knowledge (Orpheus, Inanna, Izanagi). Seekers climb sacred mountains to receive divine law (Moses on Sinai) or achieve enlightenment (Buddha under the Bodhi tree). Pilgrims travel to holy sites to access accumulated spiritual power.

These journeys transform travelers. The place itself becomes a threshold, a liminal space where normal rules suspend and transformation occurs. Returning from such places, heroes bring back gifts: wisdom, healing, prophecy, or proof of the divine. The journey to sacred places thus becomes a metaphor for spiritual development itself.
